 Voice of reason, you might take a look at the rest of the miller case. The miller case specifically stated that the right to bear arms was an individual right. The fact that it is inextricably connected to the preservation of the milita means (according to the miller decision) that the only weapons specifically covered by the second amendment are weapons that would be useful in maintaining a militia. This means military type weapons or weapons that would be useful in a military capacity.
 
 Here is the quote from the briefing:
 
 "In the absence of evidence tending to show that possession or use of a 'shotgun having a barrel of less than 18 inches in length,' which is the subject of regulation and taxation by the National Firearms Act of June 26, 1934, has some reasonable relationship to the preservation or efficiency of a well-regulated militia, it cannot be said the the Second Amendment to the Federal Constitution guarantees the right to keep and bear such an instrument, or that the statute violates such constitutional provision."
 
 "It is not within judicial notice that a shotgun having a barrel of less than 18 inches in length is any part of the ordinary military equipment or that its use could contribute to the common defense."
 
 Here is the MILLER courts definition of "militia"
 
 "The signification attributed to the term Militia appears from the debates in the Convention, the history and legislation of Colonies and States, and the writings of approved commentators.
